Award.AwardTitle: Can Practical Knowledge Modeled in a Teaching Simulator Support Mathematics Teacher Learning?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is an early-stage research study in the Research on Education and Learning program to develop and study intelligent, virtual simulations of teaching proof in high school geometry to improve the preparation of future secondary mathematics teachers. A major concern in the preparation of teachers is bridging course-based learning with practice in real classrooms. However, regular classrooms do not provide controlled situations where beginning teachers can focus on developing specific, important aspects of their teaching practice. The simulations are based on realistic classroom situations and guided by theories on teacher knowledge, but controlled via the virtual nature of the learning environment. This learning environment allows teachers to explore and rehearse new strategies for teaching with virtual students without the higher consequences of this exploration in real classrooms. This study builds on the prior work in intelligent tutors for student learning of mathematics to generalize to teacher learning. The simulation-based approach also has the potential to provide a practical framework to conduct similar studies of teaching and learning to teach in instructional situations and subjects other than the one studied here, and of learning to practice in professions other than secondary mathematics teaching. Upon completion of the study, the online, simulation-based learning environment will be available at LessonSketch (www.lessonsketch.org) for both teacher educators and teacher candidates to use.

The goal of the project is to test the operational capacity of practical rationality, a theory of teaching knowledge, by designing and exploring the use of an intelligent teaching simulator whose knowledge model is based on that theory of teaching knowledge. The project will develop two versions of the simulator: a simple version whose knowledge model uses mathematics knowledge of teaching and an advanced version that adds to the simple version elements of practical professional knowledge specified by practical rationality. The research team will explore the specific contribution of practical rationality by comparing preservice secondary mathematics teachers learning with the simple version of the simulator and preservice secondary mathematics teachers learning with the advanced version. The project will first explore where the comparison is done using paper versions of the simulators using pairs of teacher candidates and teacher educators to refine and specify a more fine-grained model of teaching knowledge and a model of scaffolding in practice-based teacher education. Then, the project will study the comparison of the two improved versions using teacher candidates. This work helps understand the added value of the practical knowledge model in supporting learning to teach in, from, and for practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The qualities of students' opportunity to learn mathematics depend on the work that teachers do with students and the content of studies; it is not enough to have good curricular resources available. In the last decades mathematics education researchers have made a variety of efforts to understand the work of mathematics teachers. While some have investigated the role that individual characteristics (e.g., beliefs, knowledge) play in teaching quality across lessons, others have investigated how the instructional context in which teachers work enables or constrains what teachers can do. In line with this second orientation, this project explored consequences of a theory that describes teachers' actions as responsive to expectations for the management of specific instructional goals. Concretely, we asked what could be learned from a simulation of a lesson in which teachers were asked to choose what an avatar teacher would say or do at various moments in a lesson in which they were shown programmed responses from students and options for what the teacher could do. At various decision points, alternatives for action the teacher could take included not only the normative choices (what in prior research we had found teachers might think they were expected to do in the context of an instructional situation) but also alternative choices that, according to reformers, might improve students' opportunity to learn. The latter included, for example, choices to invite alternative solutions from students.

 

This project constructed a simulation of teaching situated in proof in geometry. To design the simulation, we drew on prior research on teachers' management of students' engagement in proving, constructing a narrative in which the avatar teacher would run into decisions that would give them the opportunity to either act according to what would be customarily expected of them or else do other actions--some that would open up the classroom discussion and others that would close it down. In one of our studies, we compared the performance on the simulation between expert geometry teachers and nonexperts, where we considered experts to be teachers with 5 or more years of experience teaching high school geometry and scoring higher than average on mathematical knowledge for teaching geometry. Groups were found not distinguishable in regard to whether they would, on average, act as expected. But we found that nonexperts were less likely to choose to open up the discussion than experts. We also found that experts were more aware than nonexperts of the need to consider the time available before deciding whether to entertain alternative solutions. These results illustrate what can be learned about individual differences among teachers (in this case, differences in expertise) through the use of a simulation.

 

A second study used the simulation in interviews of expert geometry teachers by a novice teacher. The novice walked each expert through the simulation, asking for their advice at each decision point. This usage enabled the pair to discuss teaching in ways very different than usual in teacher preparation: They could converse about specific actions and decisions, somewhat similar to what they might talk about after observing a lesson. But the simulation context did not limit them to talk about what they could recall, as they could go back and consider alternative choices. They were also able to freeze action to discuss the pros and cons of decisions. The participants noted that the simulation provided them with the opportunity to discuss why not to do some action that was offered to them as a possible choice--something they had not experienced before in teacher learning contexts. In a third study, we investigated experimentally whether programming different types of feedback and having teachers go through the simulation with feedback could produce learning. Three different kinds of feedback were explored but the only one that produced learning gains was the feedback that reinforced normative expectations about the teacher's management of doing proofs. Other measures (knowledge of geometry for teaching and teachers' recognition of their professional obligation to students) showed no significant gains compared to the control group. These mostly unremarkable results suggest that if running through a simulation is to be used to produce teacher learning, that learning is more likely to be of a small grain size.
